attributes.action: speedily instruct the Higher Education Funding Council of England, as representative of the Elected Government of the Day, to immediately investigate the current “Destruction” of the BEAVERS RETREAT at The London School of Economics & Political Science, Old Building, Houghton Street, as a much loved social venue of long established benefit to the LSE’s current & future staff, students, alumni and its extended community and a unique place to “make a difference” to the world we live in.  We FURTHER REQUEST that the PM publicly support of the right of the LSE Environmental Initiatives Network alongside other alumni groups to seek an IMMEDIATE HALT of all work on the demolition of the Beavers Retreat (affectionately named after the schools own industrious mascot), pending the outcome of a proper and urgent investigation of this controversial “decision” by the Council of the LSE.  We further implore the PRIME MINISTER to “sign this petition today” and to urge others to do same with the practical sense of urgency required before it is too late to prevent this misguided travesty. What chance of  “Saving the Planet” if no-one can save the “Beavers Retreat” at the LSE?
attributes.action_prefix: We the undersigned petition the Prime Minister to
attributes.background:
We note the failure to publicise this decision or to engage in any consultation since the decision was taken in April.  This contravenes the schools stated policies to engage and be transparent and ethical in its decision making.

The Beavers Retreat is a civilised traditional space that has a special place in the affections of almost all alumni.  It is noted for its selection of real draught ales and the occasional warm fire.

The principle of “renovation over destruction”, of re-use, repair and recycle in that order, was not followed under the schools environmental policy.
 
We note the significant sums of money raised from Alumni are being used in part to fund an act of vandalism disrespecting the schools heritage.

We urge the Governing Council of the LSE to reverse the closure of the BR and its 32 year history serving staff, students and alumni of the school and allow this investigation to proceed in order to protect the schools international reputation.

reasons: Intended to be humorous, or has no point about government policy
